VOL. XXXI. No. 45

JAY TRACK MEN
TO MEET GETTYSBURG
Captain Gwinn to Lead Hopkins
Runners Against Invaders
CLOSE SCORE EXPECTED
Homewood Distance Men to Offset Visiting Sprint Stars
Tomorrow afternoon at 1.30 the
Blue Jay track team opens its
spring season in a dual meet with
Gettysburg College. Hopkins'
supporters will have but two opportunities this year to see the
Black and Blue .ciader-path artists perform, due to our home
and home agreement .with other
colleges which causes most of the
meets to be run away from home.
The other meet of the season to
he held at Homewood will be on
May 14, when Washington College and St. Johns will-be met in
a triangular meet.
Gettysburg should furnish very
good opposition, and the expectations are that the meet will be
very close, With the final result
hanging on the outcome of the
field events.. During the last two
Weeks the weather has kept Coach
Edwards from giving the team
any hard workouts. No practices have been called off, but the
inclement weather has prevented
the men reaching the form that
he wished them to be in for the
Opening meet.
Full Strength to Be Used

The team is not particularly
crippled, although Armstrong will
not be able to run due- to a strained ligament. Hemmeter has not
been able to get into form but if
his condition warrants he will be
placed either in the century or the
quarter.
The list of runners who • will
represent the Black and Blue as
announced by Coach Edwards
Yesterday is as follows:
100 yard dash—Pindell, Bull,
(third uncertain).
220 yard dash—Pindell, Bull,
Severance.
dash—Severance,
440 yard
Zepp, (third uncertain).
880 yard run—Wheeler, Scow,
and either Day or Zepp.
1 mile run—Gwinn, Day, (third
uncertain).
2 mile run—Schiebel, Gwinn,
hurdles—Brown and
High
Probably Hershey.
Low hurdles—Scheidt, W.,
Vivell.
High jump—Vivell, Quiik, McNeal.
Broad jump—Vivell, Hershey,
(third uncertain).
Pole vault—Scheidt, W., Quirk
and either Anderson or Thompson.
Shot put—Berger, McNeal,
Pindell.
Discuss—Berger, Wrightson,
(third uncertain).
Javelin Throw—McNeal, Wood
and Friz.
Gettysburg Unknown Quantity

Little is known about Gettysburg. Jones is perhaps their best
bet and although predictions may
be expected to go awry, yet Hopkins can hardly hope to stop this
star in his specialties, the century,

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 8, 1927

BASNSTO
'RMERS CLUB
ELECTS FOURTEEN
Fourteen men were elected
to the Barnstormers Club at
a meeting of that organization
held last Sunday night. The
meeting was held at the home
of Walter B. Swindell, Jr.,
coach of the club. A buffet
supper was served to the members and was followed by the
election.
The men who were elected
are: White, Warfield, Hoffman, Kreiling, Kolb, Blandi,
Corbin,
Berny,
Boynton,
Huey, Bird, W. Banks, Friz,
and Conklin.

Tea Dance Tomorrow

To Attend Dance

Fresh from its 13 to 1 victory
over Virginia, last week, the Hopkins lacrosse team will encounter
strong opposition when Yale University is met at Homewood Field
on Saturday. This game will test
the ability of the Hopkins defense
to the utmost. Last Saturday the
Blue Jays swamped Virginia on a
muddy field, and the defense was
given little opportunity to display its
efficiency.
The Eli stickmen, on their annual
southern invasion, are bringing
down a strong team in an effort to
check the winning streak of the
Jays, which is now entering upon
its second season.

This afternoon members of the
Yale lacrosse team and the Get-.
tysburg track team will be escorted to their hotels by the Varsity Club. The guests are expected to attend the Cotillion
Club dance tomorrow night at the

TROPHY ROOM?
When our University moved to Homewood thirteen years
ago, foreseeing administrators perceived the need of a center for
student gatherings and student activities. Accordingly, the brick
barn situated near the southerly entrance to the campus was renovated to meet the situation.
Tradition clothes our homely Barn with dearest memories.
Especially has its Trophy Room and surrounding offices become,
to a great extent, the heart of the campus.
But as we watch and listen to the pulsating of that heart today, we fail to find anything endearing or beautiful about it—at
least between the hours of ten and four. What was once a Trophy
Room has become a bums' hang-out.
To be sure, the Barn should be a place for refreshment and
pleasure. Card games in themselves are perfectly harmless. But
when those same games give rise to a constant stream of curses
and continual arguments between the players, we fail to, find
anything salutary about them. The card players constitute a
group of students who, for the most part, make themselves extremely obnoxious by their blatant clamor, their continual brawling, their utter disregard for property, public and personal, and
their lack of cleanliness.
We do not pretend to be "uplifts" or "clean-ups," but we do
suggest that the offenders either mend their ways or get out. If
no improvement is noticed, it would be well for the Student Council to exercise its prerogative as custodian of the Trophy Room.

IT CAN'T BE LONG NOW
The elimination of English Composition I from the curriculum of the College of Arts and Sciences is just another .milestone in the inauguration of the New Plan. "English Comp."
follows in the footsteps of elementary language courses, which
were stricken from the list of available subjects last year.
Not only, however, have English Composition and English
Literature I been dropped, but, as Dean Ames recently explained,
the entire range of courses open to A. B. candidates has been
materially shortened. According to the Dean's statement in the
NEWS-LETTER last month, "these courses are arranged so as to
give a well-rounded general education or to prepare for admission to the study of medicine, law, etc." With such a narrow
choice before them, however, we doubt very much whether many
students will desire to enter the College on that basis. Most young
men wanting the sort of "general education" to which the Dean
refers will want a larger choice than the revised catalogue will
offer, and, consequently, instead of not entering the undergraduate school specifically because they are told that they may not,
they will desist from doing so voluntarily.
For all practical purposes, it would seem; then, that the New
Plan is in actual operation. It is very difficult to predict how many
men will enter under the New Plan next fall, but it does not take a
genius to see that the number entering the old system will be
greatly decreased.

"YES and NO"
If you allow the truth of a statement made by a professor
English,
to the effect that 'students occasionally read assigned
of
literature, but seldom to more purpose than a feeling of defense
against a possible quiz question, it will be more remarkable that
magazines play so small.a part in undergraduate life. To be sure,
a junior recently told me that he hadn't time for such drivel as
"Cyrano de Bergerac" because. the Cosmopolitan was running
a story of Adela Rogers St. John's, but I refer rather to magazines cOntaining something better than yarns of contemporary and
peculiarly insane college life.
Certainly the average college student has a keen eye for
smut, or, if you are offended by the word, at least for the slightly
erotic, in literature. No, not "Artists and Models"; that is seldom read and never bought;—one turns its gaudy pages eagerly
while drinking a Coca-Cola--nor any of its artistic ilk. But there
are two magazines, "Beau", and "The Two Worlds Monthly"
that should logically have created a sensation. I wonder if many
do not sneer because they fear to be of the type that would read
these publications; the type of the fashionable, cultured dilettante,
the pseudo-sophisticated, smart man-about-town who talks airily
of wine, women and song, books, music, and the races. There are
few of this type at Hopkins, and all are confined to one fraternity,
but in spite of their hypocrisy, their poses and their smart smalltalk, I think we could stand more. But to return. "Beau" is one
of the most beautiful printing jobs issued; it is illustrated with
wood-cuts and prints by the most popular of impressionists ; it
has that metropolitan taste, that cultured and bored air which appeals so to worshippers of Adolph Menjou; more--it has, (here's
the climax) some of the most questionable well written stuff any
editor has dared to print. "Two Worlds," if you cannot be considered smart, contains stories by Catulle Mendes (ask Dr.
Shanks), Arthur Machen (ask a Phi Psi), David Lawrence (ask
Dad; he knows), and a host of others. Men whose writings have
the double attraction of intrinsic value and immediate appeal.
But as I said, Hopkins is either conservative or stupid. I
refer, of course, to the undergraduate school, whose reaction, if
any, to the above suggestion, will be either "I'm too busy reading 'Midsummer Night's Dream'," or "I never heard of them."
To the former I whisper, "Apple-sauce." To the latter, in case
they don't fill the gap with the Saturday Evening Post, the Cosmopolitan, Collier's, and other advertising agencies, nor yet with
such scrap-books of dull scraps as the Literary Digest, and Time,
I offer the "Golden Book." There, at least, will be found familiar
names. There one cannot possibly find anything offensively modern. Selections from every author worthy of recognition are used,
the choices are almost invariably good, the book is thick, and costs
only a quarter. No; I do not get a commission; my motives are
selfish, for I always fear the embarrassment of nothing to talk
about.
I have a sneaking suspicion that several seniors read the Review of Reviews, Harper's, and the Atlantic Monthly. If I am
right, I apologize and retire blushingly for, having presumed to
suggest. I know nothing about present-day problems, the Chinese
trouble (did you read Mencken Monday? He says "coolies" is
evidently a Chinese distortion of the American "Coolidges"), or
the Nicaraguan dispute, nor will anyone who follows my outline
for magazine reading gain any information on these unquestionably important topics, but—well, I have a course with Dr. Turner
anyway, and I always leave his class with a bloody and triumphant
feeling as if I had "maneuvered my forces with marvellous rapidity" or "handled diplomatic affairs with considerable shrewdness."
So that something witty, exciting, or perhaps a little . . . suggestive, will always appeal to me.
But I observe, on revision, that I have gotten enthusiastic.
For that I apologize. It is shocking taste for a Hopkins man to
get enthusiastic about anything even remotely associated with
study, as. magazines possibly are. Again, I notice that I have earnestly suggested to the mass that it read for amusement. All
right; don't shout at me. I'm aware that "reading isn't amusement, that Octavus Roy Cohen writes for the Post, and that the
Post costs a nickel. Besides, I hardly ever have time to read. . ."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 8, 1927

ZY

STUDY OF KEATS SUBJECT
OF DR. MILES' FOURTH
LECTURE
Poet Thought of Women As Children,
But Love of One Was Chief
Motive in Life

vho
or
tcy,
ave

ii

0.

"Keats, more so than the other
romantic poets, was a poet of
beauty. He preached no propaganda except love of beauty," Dr.
L. Wardlaw Miles declared in the
fourth of a series of lectures on
"Romantic Poets" to be delivered before the Tudor and Stuart
Club.
"John Keats, the poet, was
quite different from Keats, the
boy. In boyhood he was pugnacious; in manhood, the little he had, he was t ruly
poetic." He was, not, however,
vicious; his pugnacity was merely delight of battle. It was in
school at Enfield that he awoke
to his love of poetry. Here, reading Homer, he learned to appreciate the charm of Greek culture,
and to feel its powerful influence.
In 1817 the volume...of poetry
was published in which appeared
his famous sonnet "On Reading
Homer," which clearly--.shows his
deep feeling for the epic.
Not of Nobility

AFTER YALE GAME
Members of the CotillOn
Club will banquet at the Belvedere Hotel tomorrow night.
This dinner will precede the
dance to be sponsored by the
club, George P. Wagner, president of the organization,
stated at the last meeting.
The dance will be given in
honor of the visiting Yale lacrosse team.
Admission, the same for
couples as stags, will be one
dollar and a half.

The Blue Jay's showing last week
was impressive, especially the work
of the newcomers in the line-up,
and its followers expect a victory on
Saturday.
Captain Robinson seemed to be
handicapped by a wet field, but if
the weather is favorable this week,
Hopkins rooters should see "Robbie" in form.
Biddison seemed quite at home in
his new position, and the efforts of
the Virginia defense to check him
proved futile on every occasion.
"Tom"
delighted the fans with his
ft
accurate passing and shooting.

Thirsted for Fame

"In his descriptions, Keats
makes use of all five senses. Dr.
Miles worked this out by reading passages from "The Eve of
Saint Agnes." He weaves into
his poetry the soft beauty of nature. Towards the_end of his
life three motives, much like a
symphony, played in his life.
First sickness, which became
gradually worse. Then, the insatiable thirst for fame which
was only intensified by unfavorable criticism in The Blackwood,
and other magazines. Finally,
his love for Mary Brahn, which
ended so unhappily. All three
grew more intense until his untimely death at the age of twenty-one. "The greatest thing about
Keats," said Dr. Miles "is that his
Poetry has no moral; it is just
beautiful."

The plot, which deals primarily
with the misunderstandings that
arise from false scandal about
the relations between an old man,
his beautiful young wife, and a
third party, has very little love
interest. Jealousy is the motivating force in the drama. Several bloody duels take place off
stage and tragedy seems inevitable. .By a sudden turn of events
at the end, however, things turn
out happily for the young wife
and the third party.

The natural choice—
Out of the whole lot men pick
Chesterfield for its genuine tobacco
character—its natural good taste.

Rodgers To Play Lead

The cast includes Evans Rodgers, who takes the leading role,
Dr. John E. Uhler, president of
the playshop, John Georgi and
Ralph Townsend. The two female roles are played by Elise

ART WORK WILL FEATURE
1927 HULLABALOO
Cover Designed in Black and Gold;
Interior in Black and Blue

"The 1927 Hullabaloo promises
to be one of the best in the history
of Hopkins senior publications,"
says Charles F. Reese, Editor-inChief.
This year's book, which is to be
designed in medieval style, will contain over four hundred pages of
write-ups, features, and other material. Two Ionic columns flanking
a golden scroll bearing the title and
the University Seal in black and
gold form the cover design. The
interior will be finished in black and
blue.

MEN'S CLOTHERS
DURING PRESENT YEAR; Drop Note in Post Office. The 6, 15 and
30 NOTICES Will Get One Year FREE Subscription to the BLACK
and BLUE JAY.
The Secret Lucky Number Yearly will receive Five Yearly Subscriptions
or One Five Year Subscription FREE

Six Title Pages

Six title pages attractively colored, a feature article on the Fiftieth Anniversary, together with
numerous minor contributions enliven the volume. The pages bearing the pictures and epigrams of the
seniors portray a representation of
the old signs that hung before the
hostelries of Elizabethan England.
Each photograph is placed within
the black frame of the sign which
hangs upon a support of pale blue.
This year's senior class is somewhat smaller than those of former
years, numbering twenty less than
the class of 1926. However, the
board feels certain that the efficiency
of the business staff will overcome
the resulting financial disadvantages.
In order to carry out the original
plan of distributing the Hullabaloo
on June 1, the publication will go to
press on April 14, said Reese. All
material has been turned in and the
only remaining work to be done to
make the book complete is the arranging of the sections.

JAY TRACK MEN
TO MEET GETTYSBURG
Captain Gwinn to Lead Hopkins
Runners Against Invaders
CLOSE SCORE EXPECTED
Homewood Distance Men to Offset Visiting Sprint Stars
Tomorrow afternoon at 1.30 the
Blue Jay track team opens its
spring season in a dual meet with
Gettysburg College. Hopkins'
supporters will have but two opportunities this year to see the
Black and Blue .ciader-path artists perform, due to our home
and home agreement .with other
colleges which causes most of the
meets to be run away from home.
The other meet of the season to
he held at Homewood will be on
May 14, when Washington College and St. Johns will-be met in
a triangular meet.
Gettysburg should furnish very
good opposition, and the expectations are that the meet will be
very close, With the final result
hanging on the outcome of the
field events.. During the last two
Weeks the weather has kept Coach
Edwards from giving the team
any hard workouts. No practices have been called off, but the
inclement weather has prevented
the men reaching the form that
he wished them to be in for the
Opening meet.
Full Strength to Be Used

The team is not particularly
crippled, although Armstrong will
not be able to run due- to a strained ligament. Hemmeter has not
been able to get into form but if
his condition warrants he will be
placed either in the century or the
quarter.
The list of runners who • will
represent the Black and Blue as
announced by Coach Edwards
Yesterday is as follows:
100 yard dash—Pindell, Bull,
(third uncertain).
220 yard dash—Pindell, Bull,
Severance.
dash—Severance,

Zepp, (third uncertain).
880 yard run—Wheeler, Scow,
and either Day or Zepp.
1 mile run—Gwinn, Day, (third
uncertain).
2 mile run—Schiebel, Gwinn,
hurdles—Brown and
High
Probably Hershey.

Vivell.
High jump—Vivell, Quiik, McNeal.
Broad jump—Vivell, Hershey,
(third uncertain).
Pole vault—Scheidt, W., Quirk
and either Anderson or Thompson.
Shot put—Berger, McNeal,
Pindell.
Discuss—Berger, Wrightson,
(third uncertain).
Javelin Throw—McNeal, Wood
and Friz.

bet and although predictions may
be expected to go awry, yet Hopkins can hardly hope to stop this
star in his specialties, the century,

supper was served to the members and was followed by the
election.

are: White, Warfield, Hoffman, Kreiling, Kolb, Blandi,
Corbin,
Berny,
Boynton,
Huey, Bird, W. Banks, Friz,
and Conklin.

TROPHY ROOM?
When our University moved to Homewood thirteen years
ago, foreseeing administrators perceived the need of a center for
student gatherings and student activities. Accordingly, the brick
barn situated near the southerly entrance to the campus was renovated to meet the situation.
Tradition clothes our homely Barn with dearest memories.
Especially has its Trophy Room and surrounding offices become,
to a great extent, the heart of the campus.
But as we watch and listen to the pulsating of that heart today, we fail to find anything endearing or beautiful about it—at
least between the hours of ten and four. What was once a Trophy
Room has become a bums' hang-out.
To be sure, the Barn should be a place for refreshment and
pleasure. Card games in themselves are perfectly harmless. But
when those same games give rise to a constant stream of curses
and continual arguments between the players, we fail to, find
anything salutary about them. The card players constitute a
group of students who, for the most part, make themselves extremely obnoxious by their blatant clamor, their continual brawling, their utter disregard for property, public and personal, and
their lack of cleanliness.
We do not pretend to be "uplifts" or "clean-ups," but we do
suggest that the offenders either mend their ways or get out. If
no improvement is noticed, it would be well for the Student Council to exercise its prerogative as custodian of the Trophy Room.

IT CAN'T BE LONG NOW
The elimination of English Composition I from the curriculum of the College of Arts and Sciences is just another .milestone in the inauguration of the New Plan. "English Comp."
follows in the footsteps of elementary language courses, which
were stricken from the list of available subjects last year.
Not only, however, have English Composition and English
Literature I been dropped, but, as Dean Ames recently explained,
the entire range of courses open to A. B. candidates has been
materially shortened. According to the Dean's statement in the
NEWS-LETTER last month, "these courses are arranged so as to
give a well-rounded general education or to prepare for admission to the study of medicine, law, etc." With such a narrow
choice before them, however, we doubt very much whether many
students will desire to enter the College on that basis. Most young
men wanting the sort of "general education" to which the Dean
refers will want a larger choice than the revised catalogue will
offer, and, consequently, instead of not entering the undergraduate school specifically because they are told that they may not,
they will desist from doing so voluntarily.
For all practical purposes, it would seem; then, that the New
Plan is in actual operation. It is very difficult to predict how many
men will enter under the New Plan next fall, but it does not take a
genius to see that the number entering the old system will be
greatly decreased.

"YES and NO"
If you allow the truth of a statement made by a professor
English,
to the effect that 'students occasionally read assigned
of
literature, but seldom to more purpose than a feeling of defense
against a possible quiz question, it will be more remarkable that
magazines play so small.a part in undergraduate life. To be sure,
a junior recently told me that he hadn't time for such drivel as
"Cyrano de Bergerac" because. the Cosmopolitan was running
a story of Adela Rogers St. John's, but I refer rather to magazines cOntaining something better than yarns of contemporary and
peculiarly insane college life.
Certainly the average college student has a keen eye for
smut, or, if you are offended by the word, at least for the slightly
erotic, in literature. No, not "Artists and Models"; that is seldom read and never bought;—one turns its gaudy pages eagerly
while drinking a Coca-Cola--nor any of its artistic ilk. But there
are two magazines, "Beau", and "The Two Worlds Monthly"
that should logically have created a sensation. I wonder if many
do not sneer because they fear to be of the type that would read
these publications; the type of the fashionable, cultured dilettante,
the pseudo-sophisticated, smart man-about-town who talks airily
of wine, women and song, books, music, and the races. There are
few of this type at Hopkins, and all are confined to one fraternity,
but in spite of their hypocrisy, their poses and their smart smalltalk, I think we could stand more. But to return. "Beau" is one
of the most beautiful printing jobs issued; it is illustrated with
wood-cuts and prints by the most popular of impressionists ; it
has that metropolitan taste, that cultured and bored air which appeals so to worshippers of Adolph Menjou; more--it has, (here's
the climax) some of the most questionable well written stuff any
editor has dared to print. "Two Worlds," if you cannot be considered smart, contains stories by Catulle Mendes (ask Dr.
Shanks), Arthur Machen (ask a Phi Psi), David Lawrence (ask
Dad; he knows), and a host of others. Men whose writings have
the double attraction of intrinsic value and immediate appeal.
But as I said, Hopkins is either conservative or stupid. I
refer, of course, to the undergraduate school, whose reaction, if
any, to the above suggestion, will be either "I'm too busy reading 'Midsummer Night's Dream'," or "I never heard of them."
To the former I whisper, "Apple-sauce." To the latter, in case
they don't fill the gap with the Saturday Evening Post, the Cosmopolitan, Collier's, and other advertising agencies, nor yet with
such scrap-books of dull scraps as the Literary Digest, and Time,
I offer the "Golden Book." There, at least, will be found familiar
names. There one cannot possibly find anything offensively modern. Selections from every author worthy of recognition are used,
the choices are almost invariably good, the book is thick, and costs
only a quarter. No; I do not get a commission; my motives are
selfish, for I always fear the embarrassment of nothing to talk
about.
I have a sneaking suspicion that several seniors read the Review of Reviews, Harper's, and the Atlantic Monthly. If I am
right, I apologize and retire blushingly for, having presumed to
suggest. I know nothing about present-day problems, the Chinese
trouble (did you read Mencken Monday? He says "coolies" is
evidently a Chinese distortion of the American "Coolidges"), or
the Nicaraguan dispute, nor will anyone who follows my outline
for magazine reading gain any information on these unquestionably important topics, but—well, I have a course with Dr. Turner
anyway, and I always leave his class with a bloody and triumphant
feeling as if I had "maneuvered my forces with marvellous rapidity" or "handled diplomatic affairs with considerable shrewdness."
So that something witty, exciting, or perhaps a little . . . suggestive, will always appeal to me.
But I observe, on revision, that I have gotten enthusiastic.
For that I apologize. It is shocking taste for a Hopkins man to
get enthusiastic about anything even remotely associated with
study, as. magazines possibly are. Again, I notice that I have earnestly suggested to the mass that it read for amusement. All
right; don't shout at me. I'm aware that "reading isn't amusement, that Octavus Roy Cohen writes for the Post, and that the
Post costs a nickel. Besides, I hardly ever have time to read. . ."

STUDY OF KEATS SUBJECT
OF DR. MILES' FOURTH
LECTURE
Poet Thought of Women As Children,
But Love of One Was Chief
Motive in Life

vho
or
tcy,
ave

ii

0.

"Keats, more so than the other
romantic poets, was a poet of
beauty. He preached no propaganda except love of beauty," Dr.
L. Wardlaw Miles declared in the
fourth of a series of lectures on
"Romantic Poets" to be delivered before the Tudor and Stuart
Club.
"John Keats, the poet, was
quite different from Keats, the
boy. In boyhood he was pugnacious; in manhood, the little he had, he was t ruly
poetic." He was, not, however,
vicious; his pugnacity was merely delight of battle. It was in
school at Enfield that he awoke
to his love of poetry. Here, reading Homer, he learned to appreciate the charm of Greek culture,
and to feel its powerful influence.
In 1817 the volume...of poetry
was published in which appeared
his famous sonnet "On Reading
Homer," which clearly--.shows his
deep feeling for the epic.

AFTER YALE GAME
Members of the CotillOn
Club will banquet at the Belvedere Hotel tomorrow night.
This dinner will precede the
dance to be sponsored by the
club, George P. Wagner, president of the organization,
stated at the last meeting.
The dance will be given in
honor of the visiting Yale lacrosse team.
Admission, the same for
couples as stags, will be one
dollar and a half.

Biddison seemed quite at home in
his new position, and the efforts of
the Virginia defense to check him
proved futile on every occasion.

ft
accurate passing and shooting.

Thirsted for Fame

"In his descriptions, Keats
makes use of all five senses. Dr.
Miles worked this out by reading passages from "The Eve of
Saint Agnes." He weaves into
his poetry the soft beauty of nature. Towards the_end of his
life three motives, much like a
symphony, played in his life.
First sickness, which became
gradually worse. Then, the insatiable thirst for fame which
was only intensified by unfavorable criticism in The Blackwood,
and other magazines. Finally,
his love for Mary Brahn, which
ended so unhappily. All three
grew more intense until his untimely death at the age of twenty-one. "The greatest thing about
Keats," said Dr. Miles "is that his
Poetry has no moral; it is just
beautiful."

The plot, which deals primarily
with the misunderstandings that
arise from false scandal about
the relations between an old man,
his beautiful young wife, and a
third party, has very little love
interest. Jealousy is the motivating force in the drama. Several bloody duels take place off
stage and tragedy seems inevitable. .By a sudden turn of events
at the end, however, things turn
out happily for the young wife
and the third party.

The natural choice—
Out of the whole lot men pick
Chesterfield for its genuine tobacco
character—its natural good taste.

ART WORK WILL FEATURE
1927 HULLABALOO
Cover Designed in Black and Gold;
Interior in Black and Blue

"The 1927 Hullabaloo promises
to be one of the best in the history
of Hopkins senior publications,"
says Charles F. Reese, Editor-inChief.
This year's book, which is to be
designed in medieval style, will contain over four hundred pages of
write-ups, features, and other material. Two Ionic columns flanking
a golden scroll bearing the title and
the University Seal in black and
gold form the cover design. The
interior will be finished in black and
blue.

MEN'S CLOTHERS
DURING PRESENT YEAR; Drop Note in Post Office. The 6, 15 and
30 NOTICES Will Get One Year FREE Subscription to the BLACK
and BLUE JAY.
The Secret Lucky Number Yearly will receive Five Yearly Subscriptions
or One Five Year Subscription FREE

Six Title Pages

Six title pages attractively colored, a feature article on the Fiftieth Anniversary, together with
numerous minor contributions enliven the volume. The pages bearing the pictures and epigrams of the
seniors portray a representation of
the old signs that hung before the
hostelries of Elizabethan England.
Each photograph is placed within
the black frame of the sign which
hangs upon a support of pale blue.
This year's senior class is somewhat smaller than those of former
years, numbering twenty less than
the class of 1926. However, the
board feels certain that the efficiency
of the business staff will overcome
the resulting financial disadvantages.
In order to carry out the original
plan of distributing the Hullabaloo
on June 1, the publication will go to
press on April 14, said Reese. All
material has been turned in and the
only remaining work to be done to
make the book complete is the arranging of the sections.
